title: [REEF-469] Assign data splits to specific evaluators
body:
This commit allows to assign data splits to the different evaluators using the DataLoadingService.
Several changes were done. 
The main one is to inject a strategy into InputFormatLoadingService, which is in charge of assigning splits to evaluators.
New data types needed to be created. For example, DataPartition, which is just a folder, but has a location field, where the user can specify where she would like to load that data into (in certain node or rack).
We have LocationAwareJobConfs now, which binds the typical hadoop JobConf and the DataPartition objects.
I had to create external constructors for them. And removed unnecessary ones.
I also removed the EvaluatorToPartitionMapper class, most of its logic has been placed in the AbstractEvaluatorToSplitStrategy one.

JIRA:
  [REEF-469](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/REEF-469)

Pull Request:
  This closes

title: [REEF-468] DataLoader should support user-defined number of compute and data requests
body:
This commit allows to request a user-defined number of compute and data evaluators to the DataLoader.
Each evaluator can be requested to run in particular locations, using the rack information.
As there are some clients of the DataLoadingRequestBuilder, we maintain its previous functionality, though we marked several fields as deprecated.
There is still pending to implement the different strategies on how to assign partitions to the different evaluators. For now, we use the previous implementation (tries to match the host, if it cannot, assigns the partitions randomly).
Also needed to update EvaluatorRequest.Builder to make "cloning" easier.

JIRA:
[REEF-468](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/REEF-468)

Pull Request:
This closes

This PR is to sign debug build as well to avoid the issue so that both debug and release build can share the same AssemblyInfo file.

title: [REEF-450] Introduce Org.Apache.REEF.IO.PartitionedData
body:
This change adds `Org.Apache.REEF.IO.PartitionedData` which is a minimal API to represent partitioned data sets.

This change also introduces `Org.Apache.REEF.IO.PartitionedData.Random`, which is an implementation of `Org.Apache.REEF.IO.PartitionedData` for a given number of partitions with a fixed number of random bytes per partition.

Lastly, this introduces `Org.Apache.REEF.IO.Tests` as the test project for `Org.Apache.REEF.IO`. Unit Tests are included for `Org.Apache.REEF.IO.PartitionedData.Random`.

JIRA:
  [REEF-450](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/REEF-450)

title: [REEF-454] Allow for per-job queues
body:
This adds `YarnDriverConfiguration` that can be filled out by an application and merged into their DriverConfiguration to set the queue to submit the job to.

This also makes sure the `YarnClientConfiguration.YARN_QUEUE_NAME` is actually used (it wasn't). It now provides the default for when the new per-job setting isn't used.

Lastly, this change deprecates `JobSubmissionEvent.getQueue()` which was never used in the first place. Its purpose is now served by the mechanism introduced here.

JIRA:
  [REEF-454](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/REEF-454)

title: [REEF-453]  Race condition in GroupCommunication Client initialization
body:
In GroupCommClient constructor, we register the task node to Name Server first, then instantiate CommunicationGroupClient, which will instantiate Operators and register handlers. In Operator constructors, we check if its parents and children are all registered based on the topology. There is a chance that a parent or a child was registered, but haven't completed the initialization, resulting a race condition.

This PR moves the registration in GroupCommClient as the last line in the constructor. And movs the initialize checking out of the Operator constructors. Initialize will be called when client gets Operator from CommunicationGroupClient. This would ensure all the registration happens after constructors. And registration checking happens after all the constructors.

JIRA: REEF-453(https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/REEF-453)

This closes #

title: [REEF-416] Create API to specify racks in EvaluatorRequests
body:
With this commit, evaluators can now be asked to run in different nodes or
racks. Nodes should be node names. Racks can be fully qualified names. Also the
star wildcard can be used at the end. For example, in order to ask for
evaluators in any rack in datacenter 2, you can do /dc2/\* It includes a new
EvaluatorRequest constructor, and it deprecates the descriptor interface.
Updated UTs (which also helped in fixing a bug)

title: [REEF-184] Allow NetworkService to add more than one message handlers
body:
This pull request addressed the issue by
- Introduce an interface of `NetworkServiceClient`
- Implement `DefaultNetworkServiceImpl` which is an implementation of `NetworkServiceClient`
- NetworkServiceClient is a singleton.
- Users register their codec, eventHandler, and linkListener. NetworkServiceClient registers them and creates a ConnectionFactory. `networkService.registerConnectionFactory(clientServiceId, codec,
  eventHandler, linkListener)`
- After the registeration, users can get a ConnectionFactory `<T> ConnectionFactory<T>
  networkService.getConnectionFactory(clientServiceId)`
- Users can call `Connection<T>
  connectionFactory.newConnection(Identifier destId)` in order to create a connection
  between destId and local. 

Acknowledgement: Collaborates with @gwsshs22 (GeonWoo Kim)

JIRA: [REEF-184](http://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/REEF-184)

title: [REEF-418]: Group Communication breaks down on actual cluster
body:
After the recent merge (see REEF-260), we found that once we run PipelineBroadcastAndBroadcast Reduce on actual cluster it fails while if we run it locally it passes. We found the issue to be in the WritableNetworkService where while registering observer we map it to a particular local IP address rather than any.
The aim of this JIRA is to make this one line change in the WritableNetworkService.
This addressed the issue by
- Registering observer in DefaultRemoteManager with IpAddress.Any in WritableNetworkService
  JIRA: [REEF-418](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/REEF-418)

title: [REEF-409] Pass the rackName from the runtime to the top of REEF stack
body:
This work bubbles up the rack information from the runtime (after the resource is allocated) towards the evaluators allocation handlers.
The ResourceAllocationEvent interface now includes an optional rack name, which is populated by the respective runtimes when the resource is allocated.
The ProcessContainer is created with a null rack for now, it ends up using the default one.
Added a unit test that tests the whole cycle, checking if the default rack is the one retrieved.

JIRA:
  [REEF-409](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/REEF-409)

This closes

title: [REEF-393] OutputService for writing files to filesystem
body:
This addressed the issue by
- implementing OutputService.
- implementing an example application using OutputService.

JIRA: [REEF-393](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/REEF-393)

`OutputService` retains an `OutputStreamProvider`. Different `OutputStreamProvider`s can be injected depending on the current runtime (e.g., Yarn or local). Each task asks the `OutputStreamProvider` for an `OutputStream` by giving {name}. `OutputStreamProvider` provides each task with an `OutputStream` to the file whose path is "{output}/{name}/{task_id}" where {output} is injected by Tang. Of course, two or more `OutputStream`s with different names can be provided with each task. The goal of this service is to enable each task to write outputs without considering the current runtime and collision with other tasks.

In the example, three tasks create an output stream using 'hello' as a {name}. Then they write "Hello REEF!" on the stream. What they write is stored in the file whose path is "{output}/hello/{task_id}". 
You can run this example on Yarn by using the following command:
`yarn jar lang/java/reef-examples/target/reef-examples-{reef-version}-shaded.jar org.apache.reef.examples.data.output.OutputServiceREEF -local false -output {output}`
You can run this example locally by using the following command:
`java -cp lang/java/reef-examples/target/reef-examples-{reef-version}-shaded.jar org.apache.reef.examples.data.output.OutputServiceREEF -local true -output {output}`
Set {output} the path of the output directory.

title: [REEF-409] Pass the rackName from the runtime to the top of REEF stack
body:
This work bubbles up the rack information from the runtime (after the resource is allocated) towards the evaluators allocation handlers.
The ResourceAllocationEvent interface now includes an optional rack name, which is populated by the respective runtimes when the resource is allocated.
The ProcessContainer is created with a null rack for now, it ends up using the default.
Added a unit test that tests the whole cycle, checking if the default rack is the one retrieved.

JIRA:
  [REEF-409](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/REEF-409)

This closes

title: [REEF-403] Throw exception when serializing Lists in AvroConfigurationSerializer
body:
We currently don't support lists and silently ignore them. This change fixes the latter: We now throw an exception when encountering a non-empty list.

JIRA:
  [REEF-403](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/REEF-403)

title: [REEF-397]: Fix violations of FinalClass and HideUtilityClassConstructor checkstyles
body:
This addressed the issue by
- declaring classes as final when required by FinalClass check
- adding private constructors to utility classes
- suppressing HideUtilityClassConstructor warnings for classes which produced false positives

JIRA: [REEF-397](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/REEF-397)

title: [REEF-398]: Fix violations of ArrayTypeStyle checkstyle
body:
This addressed the issue by
- converting C-style arrays (String args[]) to Java-style (String[] args)

JIRA: [REEF-398](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/REEF-398)

title: [REEF-395] Implement ClassHierarchySerializer using Avro on the Java side
body:
This addressed the issue by
- Defining the avro schema for class hierarchy
- Implementing the AvroClassHierarchy
- Define ClassHierarchySerializer interface and implement an Avro version
- Replace the class hierarchy serializer for the round trip tests
- Leave TODO comments for the future issues to resolve when we revisit REEF-148
- Mark the `ProtocolBufferClassHierarchy` class as deprecated

p.s.
There was an additional change for the types in Avro. By default, Avro uses `CharSequence` for the string field: In the Java code, we should convert the types between `String` and `CharSequence` all the time. I could change the configuration to use `String` for the string field in the `pom.xml`. There was only one class (`org/apache/reef/io/network/naming/serialization/NamingLookupRequestCodec.java`) that is affected by this change and the conflict was resolved by changing only one type.

title: [REEF-261]: Make the GroupCommunicationOperator layer memory efficient by introducing StreamingCodec
body:
[REEF-261]: Make the GroupCommunicationOperator layer memory efficient by introducing StreamingCodec

This addressed the issue by
- allowing users directly to write streaming codecs.
- allowing users directly to write non-streaming codecs. In this case we write the wrapper code that directly converts this codec in to streamingcodec

JIRA: [REEF-261](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/REEF-261)

title: [REEF-184] Allow NetworkService to add more than one message handlers
body:
This pull request contains the following things: 
- Refactoring NetworkService to support multiple types (multiple client
  services, such as GroupComm and Shuffle)
- Making NameServer injectable 
- Making NameClient injectable ( implements NameClientLocal looking up local Nameserver)
- Porting new NetworkService to GroupComm and BGD, Broadcast examples. 

Acknowledgement: Collaborates with @gwsshs22 (GeonWoo Kim)

JIRA: [REEF-184](http://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/REEF-184)

title: [REEF-260]: Make the GroupCommunicationLayer memory efficient by introducing streaming and building on top of StreamingNetworkService Layer
body:
[REEF-260]: Make the GroupCommunicationLayer memory efficient by introducing streaming and building on top of StreamingNetworkService Layer

This addressed the issue by
- Adding Writable GroupCommunicationMessage. There are two classes one GeneralGroupCommunicationMessage which is independent of message type and is visible to Network service and other type specific communication message visible to operators.
- Making the current operators Writable.

JIRA: [REEF-260](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/REEF-260)

title: [REEF-390]  Allow serialized configuration pass to Evaluator as a string
body:
Currently, some of the Nodes were dropped by proto buffer libary when Java deserializes a class hierarchy created in C#, resulting in Java driver not able to deserialize service configurations passed from C# which use those classes. A typical example is nested generic types for ICodec which client would like to pass to the evaluator as part of the service config.

This PR:
*Add a new API GetServiceConfiguration to allow the client to pass additional service configuration
   IConfiguration GetServiceConfiguration(params IConfiguration[] clientConfigurations);
*Inside this method, serialize the clientConfigurations as a string and bind it with service config
*Updated ServiceConfiguration to inject the named parameter to get the string config and deserialze it, and then merge it with the service config
*Test cases are added for the hcange

JIRA: REEF-390(https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/REEF-390)

This closes #

HelloREEF is adapted to no longer generate the class hiearchy.

title: [REEF-368]: Avoid holding Wake schedule lock while calling event hand…
body:
…lers

  This removes the call to handle an idle event to before the schedule lock
  is taken.

  This should avoid the deadlock situation seen in REEF-294, where a separate
  thread holds a lock needed by the idle event handler, and then waits for
  the schedule lock. Now the idle event handler call will not be holding the
  schedule lock.

JIRA:
  [REEF-368] https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/REEF-368

title: [REEF-307] Make CRLF line terminator consistent in .Net code
body:
In releasing 0.11.0 version, we noticed clrf line terminators in script files like DISCLAIMER, HEADER, LICENSE, NOTICE, .md file, and pom.xml file if they are check-out and then check-in through windows machine. This change is to enforce those files terminated with lf, and .Net files such as .cpp. .cs, .csproj, terminated with crlf. Default is still auto to avoid messing up.

To verify it, after checkout the code, you might need to
git rm --cached -r .
git reset --hard

JIRA: REEF-307(https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/REEF-307)

This closes #
